The hospital corridors echoed with an unusual tension that Thursday morning, though Dr. Sarah Levinson couldn't quite put her finger on what felt different. She'd traded her waiter's apron for scrubs only six months ago, having finally completed her medical degree after years of night shifts at Romano's Diner in downtown Dallas. The transition from taking orders for chicken fried steak to taking vital signs had been jarring, but nothing could have prepared her for what she was about to encounter.

The first sign something was amiss came when Nurse Patricia Williams didn't show up for her shift. Patricia was notorious for her punctuality—she'd arrive exactly seventeen minutes early every day, coffee in hand, already reviewing patient charts. When her replacement mentioned that Patricia had called in with a peculiar story about being "wrapped up" in some kind of art project, Sarah felt the first flutter of unease in her chest.

"Wrapped up how?" Sarah asked, adjusting her stethoscope as they walked past the pediatric wing.

"That's the thing," replied Nurse Jenkins, a heavyset woman whose shoes squeaked against the linoleum with every step. "She said she couldn't move her arms properly, something about toilet paper and paint. Made no sense whatsoever. Administration thinks she might be having some kind of breakdown."

Sarah nodded absently, but her mind was already racing. She'd heard whispers over the past week about strange disappearances, about nurses who would simply vanish for hours at a time before reappearing with confused expressions and mysterious white residue on their uniforms. The other doctors dismissed it as gossip, the kind of idle chatter that flourished in any workplace where people worked long hours under stress.

But Sarah remembered something from her waitressing days that made her take these stories more seriously. She'd learned to pay attention to patterns, to the subtle signs that something was building toward a crisis. In the restaurant business, you learned to spot trouble before it erupted—the customer who'd had one drink too many, the kitchen staff member who was about to snap under pressure, the small incidents that preceded the big disasters.

The morning rounds proceeded normally until they reached the seventh floor, where the geriatric ward housed some of their most vulnerable patients. Sarah was checking on Mrs. Henderson, an eighty-three-year-old woman recovering from hip surgery, when she heard the screaming.

It wasn't the typical hospital screaming—not pain or fear or medical emergency—but something else entirely. A sound of pure bewilderment mixed with what could only be described as artistic frustration. Sarah dropped Mrs. Henderson's chart and rushed toward the sound, her heart pounding as she rounded the corner into the main hallway.

What she saw defied immediate comprehension. A figure that had to be at least nine feet tall was carefully, almost tenderly, wrapping Nurse Rodriguez in what appeared to be several layers of toilet paper. The giant moved with surprising delicacy, rotating the terrified nurse like a mannequin while applying the paper in precise, overlapping spirals. But what made the scene even more surreal was that Rodriguez's face and hands had been painted in brilliant shades of blue and gold, creating an effect that was simultaneously beautiful and deeply unsettling.

"Stop!" Sarah shouted, though her voice came out as more of a croak than a command.

The giant paused and turned toward her, and Sarah found herself looking into the most profoundly sad eyes she'd ever encountered. The face was feminine, with features that might have been considered beautiful if not for their impossible scale and the expression of grief so deep it seemed to emanate from every pore. Tears the size of raindrops fell steadily from those enormous eyes, creating small puddles on the hospital floor.

"I'm making them beautiful," the giant said, her voice a low rumble that seemed to vibrate through Sarah's bones. "They work so hard, they deserve to be beautiful."

Sarah forced herself to take a step closer, fighting every instinct that screamed at her to run. "What's your name?"

"Lyn," the giant replied, never stopping her careful wrapping motions. "I used to be smaller. I used to be different. But the sadness made me grow."

"The sadness?"

Lyn's massive hands paused in their work, and for a moment the only sound was Nurse Rodriguez's muffled whimpering from beneath her toilet paper cocoon. "My daughter worked in a hospital. She took care of people, just like these beautiful nurses. But nobody took care of her when she needed it most."

Sarah felt her training kick in, the same calm professionalism that had helped her handle difficult customers during her waitressing years. "I'm sorry about your daughter, Lyn. But these nurses—they're scared. They have families who need them to come home."

"They will go home," Lyn said, carefully tucking the end of the toilet paper into Rodriguez's wrapping. "They'll go home more beautiful than when they left. Art makes everything better. Art makes pain into something people can look at."

Before Sarah could respond, Lyn lifted the wrapped nurse with impossible gentleness and placed her in a wheelchair that she'd apparently commandeered from somewhere else in the hospital. Rodriguez sat there like an enormous toilet paper sculpture, only her painted face visible, eyes wide with shock but otherwise unharmed.

"You see?" Lyn said, stepping back to admire her work. "Beautiful. Peaceful. Safe."

Sarah realized with growing horror that this wasn't random violence or even mental illness in any conventional sense. This was grief transformed into something else entirely, grief that had somehow taken physical form and grown beyond all normal boundaries. The giant's movements were too purposeful, too artistic, too filled with genuine care to be the product of simple madness.

"How many nurses have you... decorated?" Sarah asked, trying to keep her voice steady.

Lyn's expression brightened slightly, the way a child's face might light up when asked about a favorite hobby. "Seven so far today. Each one different colors, different patterns. The morning shift nurses are blues and greens—cool colors for cool morning light. The afternoon shift will be warmer. Oranges and reds and yellows."

Sarah's mind raced as she tried to process this information. Seven nurses. That explained the staffing shortages, the confused phone calls, the growing sense of chaos that had been building throughout the morning. But where were the others? And more importantly, how had a nine-foot-tall giant managed to move through the hospital without setting off every alarm and security protocol they had?

As if reading her thoughts, Lyn gestured toward a supply closet whose door stood slightly ajar. "They're resting in there. Waiting for the unveiling."

Sarah edged toward the closet, her hands shaking as she reached for the handle. Inside, arranged like an art installation, sat six more toilet paper wrapped figures. Each one had been painted in different color schemes, and each sat perfectly still in what appeared to be states of resigned bewilderment. They were breathing, they were unharmed, but they were essentially immobilized by their elaborate wrappings.

"This has to stop, Lyn," Sarah said, turning back to face the giant. "These people aren't art supplies. They're human beings with lives and responsibilities."

Lyn's face crumpled, and a fresh wave of tears began flowing down her cheeks. "But they're so tired. They work so hard. When I wrap them up, they can rest. When I paint them, they become something more than just tired nurses in a difficult world."

Sarah found herself in the strangest position of her life—trying to provide therapy to a grief-stricken giant who was systematically gift-wrapping the hospital staff. Her medical training hadn't covered this scenario, but her years of dealing with difficult customers had taught her something about de-escalation and finding common ground with people who were acting irrationally.

"Tell me about your daughter," she said, settling into a chair that put her roughly at eye level with Lyn's kneecaps. "What was her name?"

The giant's expression softened immediately. "Emma. Emma Louise Patterson. She was a pediatric nurse at Children's Memorial. Twenty-six years old, the most beautiful heart you ever saw." Lyn's voice grew quieter, more distant. "She worked double shifts because they were short-staffed. She slept four hours a night because there was always another child who needed care. She gave everything she had to that job."

"What happened to her?"

Lyn's massive form seemed to shrink slightly, her shoulders sagging under the weight of memory. "Car accident on her way home from a thirty-six hour shift. She fell asleep at the wheel. The grief... it changed me. Made me bigger. Made me want to protect all the other nurses, all the other daughters who give too much of themselves away."

Sarah felt her heart breaking for this strange, impossible woman. The logic was twisted, but the love behind it was genuine. Lyn wasn't trying to hurt anyone—she was trying to protect them in the only way her grief-transformed mind could conceive.

"Emma sounds like she was an amazing person," Sarah said carefully. "But do you think she would want you to frighten her colleagues? To wrap them up so they can't do their jobs?"

Lyn considered this question with obvious difficulty, her enormous brow furrowed in concentration. Around them, the hospital continued to function, though Sarah could hear the growing commotion as more staff discovered the situation. Soon, security would arrive, probably followed by police, and this delicate moment of communication would be lost in chaos and conflict.

"I don't know," Lyn admitted finally. "I just know that the sadness gets so big sometimes that I have to do something with it. And when I'm painting, when I'm wrapping, it feels like I'm taking care of people the way Emma used to take care of people."Sarah felt a sudden clarity wash over her, the same intuitive understanding that had helped her navigate countless difficult situations during her years in the service industry. She stood up slowly, making sure her movements were calm and non-threatening, and walked over to where Nurse Rodriguez sat in her toilet paper cocoon. With gentle fingers, she began to unwrap the frightened woman, peeling away layer after layer of the elaborate binding.

"What are you doing?" Lyn asked, her voice rising in alarm. "She's not finished yet. The paint needs more time to set, and the wrapping provides the structural integrity for the piece."

"I'm helping her breathe better," Sarah explained, continuing her careful work. "You know, Lyn, there might be a different way to honor Emma's memory. A way that helps people instead of frightening them." As she worked, Sarah's mind was racing through possibilities, drawing on every ounce of creativity and problem-solving ability she'd developed over her unconventional path to medicine.

Rodriguez emerged from her wrappings like a colorful butterfly, gasping with relief but still decorated in the elaborate face paint that Lyn had applied. The blue and gold design was actually quite striking, Sarah had to admit, though the terror in the nurse's eyes somewhat diminished the artistic effect. Rodriguez stumbled away toward the elevator, probably to report the situation to security, but Sarah barely noticed. Her attention was focused entirely on the giant woman whose grief had taken such an extraordinary physical form.

"Tell me more about Emma's work," Sarah said, settling back into her chair. "What kind of art did she like? Did you two ever do creative projects together?"

Lyn's expression grew wistful, and she lowered herself carefully to sit cross-legged on the hospital floor, her massive frame still towering over Sarah even in this position. "Emma loved children's book illustrations. She used to say that a good picture could make a sick child forget their pain for a few minutes. She kept art supplies in her locker at work, would draw little pictures for her patients when she had time between rounds."

Sarah felt pieces of a plan beginning to form in her mind. "What if we could find a way to continue Emma's work? What if instead of wrapping up the nurses, you could help them create something beautiful for the children in the pediatric ward?"

The giant's tears slowed slightly, and Sarah could see genuine interest flickering in those enormous, sad eyes. "You mean... make art that helps people feel better instead of just making them look beautiful?"

"Exactly," Sarah said, her confidence growing as the idea took shape. "Emma knew that art could be healing. She used it to help children cope with difficult medical procedures. Maybe that's the real way to honor her memory—not by protecting nurses from their work, but by helping them do their work more effectively."

Lyn was quiet for a long moment, considering this possibility. Around them, Sarah could hear the distant sound of security personnel gathering, the crackling of radios and the heavy footsteps of people preparing for some kind of confrontation. She knew their time was limited, that soon this delicate conversation would be interrupted by well-meaning people who would see only a threat to be neutralized rather than a grieving mother to be helped.

"I don't know if I remember how to make helpful art," Lyn said finally, her voice small despite its physical magnitude. "The sadness makes everything I touch turn strange. I used to be a normal size, used to be a kindergarten teacher before Emma died. But the grief kept growing inside me until it changed my whole body, made me into something that doesn't fit in normal spaces anymore."

Sarah stood up and walked over to the supply closet where the other wrapped nurses sat in their various states of artistic imprisonment. "Maybe the first step is letting these nurses go back to their jobs. Then we can figure out together how to channel your creative energy into something that helps rather than hinders."

She began unwrapping the nurses one by one, carefully peeling away the toilet paper while trying to preserve as much of Lyn's artwork as possible. Each nurse had indeed been painted in different color schemes, and despite the bizarre circumstances, Sarah couldn't help but notice the genuine artistic skill involved. The color combinations were sophisticated, the application techniques showed real understanding of how paint interacted with skin tone, and there was an underlying aesthetic sensibility that spoke to years of training and practice.

"You're really talented," Sarah said as she freed the fourth nurse, a young man whose face had been transformed into an abstract landscape of purples and silvers. "Did you study art formally?"

Lyn nodded, some of her earlier enthusiasm returning. "Bachelor's degree in Fine Arts, specialized in mixed media installations. I had a studio before Emma died, was starting to get some recognition in the local gallery scene. But after the accident, I couldn't make anything that didn't turn into expressions of grief. Gallery owners don't know what to do with a nine-foot-tall artist whose work makes people cry."

The last two nurses emerged from their wrappings with expressions of relief mixed with confusion. The paint job on each was genuinely impressive, and Sarah found herself wondering if there might be a way to salvage some kind of positive outcome from this bizarre situation. The hospital could certainly use more art, especially in the children's ward, and Lyn's skills were undeniable even if her methods were unconventional.

"Listen," Sarah said, turning to address the group of newly freed nurses who stood huddled together near the supply closet, still wearing their elaborate face paint. "I know this morning has been terrifying and strange, but I think Lyn here might actually be able to help us with something important if we can find the right approach."

The nurses looked at her as if she'd lost her mind, which was probably a reasonable assessment given the circumstances. But Sarah pressed on, driven by the same instinct that had helped her recognize when a restaurant situation was about to spiral out of control and needed immediate intervention.

"The pediatric ward has been asking for months for funding to bring in art therapists and creative programs for the children," she continued. "What if instead of waiting for budget approval, we found a way to work with Lyn to create something meaningful for those kids?"**Chapter 2**

The security team arrived with all the subtlety of a small army, their heavy boots thundering down the hospital corridor just as Sarah finished unwrapping the last nurse. She could hear the sharp crackle of radio communications and the metallic clink of equipment, sounds that made Lyn visibly shrink despite her enormous size. The giant woman's shoulders hunched forward protectively, and her tears began flowing more freely as the voices grew closer. Sarah realized with growing urgency that the next few minutes would determine whether this situation escalated into a full-scale confrontation or evolved into something more constructive.

"Stay calm," Sarah whispered to Lyn, positioning herself between the giant and the approaching security team. "Let me talk to them first. Don't make any sudden movements, and try to keep your voice soft. They're going to be scared too, and scared people sometimes make poor decisions."

The lead security officer rounded the corner with his hand resting on his radio, his expression shifting from professional alertness to complete bewilderment as he took in the scene. Behind him, three more officers crowded into the hallway, their eyes widening as they processed the sight of a nine-foot-tall woman sitting cross-legged on the hospital floor, surrounded by nurses whose faces were decorated in elaborate painted designs. The silence stretched for several heartbeats, broken only by the distant hum of medical equipment and the soft sound of Lyn's continued weeping.

"Dr. Levinson," the lead officer said finally, his voice carefully controlled. "We received reports of some kind of disturbance on this floor. Can you explain what's happening here?"

Sarah took a deep breath, drawing on every ounce of diplomacy she'd learned during her years of dealing with upset customers and tense kitchen situations. "Officer Martinez, this is Lyn Patterson. She's an artist who's been going through some difficulties since losing her daughter, and she's been trying to express her grief through creative work. The situation has been resolved peacefully, and none of the staff members were harmed."

Martinez's eyes moved from Sarah to the painted nurses, then up to Lyn's massive form, his professional training clearly at war with the impossibility of what he was witnessing. "Ma'am, I'm going to need you to stand up slowly and keep your hands where I can see them," he said, addressing Lyn directly.

Lyn began to unfold herself from her sitting position, her movements careful and deliberate. Even with her obvious attempts to appear non-threatening, her sheer size dominated the hallway space, making the officers instinctively step backward. Sarah could see the tension building in the security team's body language, the way their hands moved unconsciously toward their equipment, and she knew she had only moments before someone decided that force was the appropriate response to this unprecedented situation.

"She's grieving," Sarah said quickly, stepping slightly closer to Martinez while keeping her voice calm and professional. "Her daughter Emma was a pediatric nurse who died in a car accident six months ago. The grief has manifested in some unusual ways, but Lyn's fundamental intention is to help and protect healthcare workers, not harm them. She has significant artistic training, and I believe we might be able to channel her creative energy into something beneficial for the hospital."

One of the younger officers, a woman whose name tag read "Cooper," was staring at Lyn with an expression that mixed fear with fascination. "How is she so... large?" Cooper asked, the question clearly slipping out before she could stop herself.

Lyn wiped her enormous eyes with the back of her hand, leaving streaks in the paint that had somehow transferred from her artistic work. "The sadness made me grow," she said, her voice barely above a whisper but still audible throughout the hallway. "Every day after Emma died, I got a little bigger. The doctors say it's impossible, but grief doesn't follow medical rules."

Sarah seized on this moment of human connection, recognizing that Cooper's question had broken through some of the professional distance that was keeping the security team from seeing Lyn as a person rather than simply a threat. "Officer Cooper, have you ever lost someone close to you?" she asked gently.

Cooper nodded, her expression softening slightly. "My brother, two years ago. Military deployment." Her eyes remained fixed on Lyn's face, seeming to recognize something in the giant's expression of loss.

"Then you understand that grief can change people in profound ways," Sarah continued. "Lyn's transformation may be more dramatic than most, but the underlying emotion is something we can all recognize. The question now is whether we respond to her pain with more pain, or whether we find a way to help her transform that grief into something healing."

Martinez looked between his officers, clearly struggling with a situation that fell well outside standard security protocols. The hospital's administrative policies had certainly never anticipated the need to deal with a grief-stricken giant who expressed her emotions through unauthorized art installations. Meanwhile, the painted nurses had clustered together near the elevator, some of them beginning to clean the artwork from their faces while others seemed almost reluctant to wash away the elaborate designs.

"Dr. Levinson," Martinez said finally, "I appreciate what you're trying to do here, but I have to think about the safety of everyone in this hospital. We can't have someone of this size moving freely through the building, regardless of their intentions."

Before Sarah could respond, a new voice joined the conversation from the direction of the elevator bank. "What exactly is going on here?" The voice belonged to Dr. Patricia Hendricks, the hospital's chief administrator, a woman whose reputation for decisive problem-solving was matched only by her ability to find creative solutions to bureaucratic challenges. She emerged from the elevator with her characteristic brisk stride, then stopped abruptly as she took in the scene before her.

Dr. Hendricks was a small woman in her early sixties, with silver hair pulled back in a practical bun and the kind of sharp, intelligent eyes that missed very little. She had been running Presbyterian Hospital for over fifteen years, navigating everything from budget crises to medical emergencies to public relations disasters. But Sarah could see that even her considerable experience hadn't prepared her for the sight of a giant woman surrounded by security officers and paint-decorated nursing staff.

"Dr. Levinson," Hendricks said, her voice maintaining its professional calm despite the obvious confusion in her expression, "perhaps you could provide me with a brief summary of the current situation."

Sarah realized that this moment represented a crucial turning point. Dr. Hendricks had the authority to make decisions that could either escalate this situation into a full emergency response or create space for the more creative solution that was beginning to form in Sarah's mind. Everything depended on whether she could present Lyn's story in a way that emphasized the potential opportunities rather than just the obvious problems.

"Dr. Hendricks, I'd like you to meet Lyn Patterson," Sarah began, gesturing toward the giant woman who was trying to make herself appear as small as possible despite her impossible size. "Lyn is a professional artist with a bachelor's degree in Fine Arts. She lost her daughter Emma six months ago—Emma was a pediatric nurse at Children's Memorial. Lyn's grief has manifested in some unusual physical changes, and she's been trying to process her loss through creative expression."

Hendricks walked closer to Lyn, her head tilted back to make eye contact with the giant. "I'm very sorry for your loss, Ms. Patterson," she said, her voice carrying genuine compassion. "Losing a child is one of life's most profound tragedies. But I'm sure you understand that we can't have hospital staff being... wrapped up... during their shifts."

Lyn nodded miserably, fresh tears beginning to flow down her cheeks. "I know it was wrong," she said, her voice filled with shame. "I just wanted to take care of them the way Emma used to take care of people. I wanted to make them beautiful and safe and give them a chance to rest."

Sarah stepped forward, sensing an opening. "Dr. Hendricks, what if there was a way to channel Lyn's artistic abilities toward something that actually helps the hospital? You know we've been trying to get approval for art therapy programs in the pediatric ward. What if instead of waiting for budget allocation, we found a way to work with Lyn to create something meaningful for those children?"

Hendricks was quiet for a moment, her sharp mind clearly working through the implications of what Sarah was suggesting. Around them, the security officers waited for direction, while the painted nurses continued to hover near the elevator, uncertain whether they should return to their duties or wait for further instructions. The whole scene had an surreal quality, like a tableau from some impossible dream where bureaucratic procedure collided with mythological transformation.

"Ms. Patterson," Hendricks said finally, "show me your hands."

Lyn extended her enormous hands, palms up, revealing fingers stained with various colors of paint and what appeared to be remarkable delicacy of movement despite their size. Hendricks examined them carefully, noting the way Lyn held them steady despite her emotional distress, the evidence of fine motor control that suggested genuine artistic skill.

"These are the hands of someone who's spent years developing technical proficiency," Hendricks observed. "Dr. Levinson, what exactly are you proposing?""I'm proposing a trial partnership," Sarah said, her confidence growing as she saw genuine interest flickering in Dr. Hendricks' expression. "The children's ward has been requesting art programming for months. We have dozens of young patients who are dealing with long-term treatments, extended stays, and medical procedures that create anxiety and fear. What if Lyn could work with our child life specialists to create therapeutic art experiences that actually help these kids process their medical experiences in a healthier way?"

Dr. Hendricks walked slowly around Lyn's seated form, her administrator's mind clearly calculating risks and benefits while her humanitarian instincts responded to the obvious depth of the giant woman's grief. The security officers remained alert but had relaxed slightly, following their boss's lead in treating this as a problem to be solved rather than a threat to be neutralized. Meanwhile, some of the painted nurses had begun to edge closer, their initial terror giving way to curiosity about what might happen next.

"The liability issues alone would be staggering," Hendricks said, though her tone suggested she was working through obstacles rather than dismissing the idea entirely. "Insurance coverage for a... person of unusual size... working directly with vulnerable pediatric patients. Background checks and credentialing for someone whose artistic methods are clearly unconventional. Not to mention the practical considerations of accommodating someone of Lyn's stature in spaces designed for normal-sized individuals."

Lyn's expression had begun to shift from shame to tentative hope as she listened to this conversation. "I could work in larger spaces," she offered, her voice still soft but carrying more strength than before. "The hospital chapel has high ceilings, and I noticed there's a big conference room on the third floor that might work. I don't need special furniture or equipment—just space to move and supplies to work with. And I understand about background checks and safety protocols. Emma used to talk about how important those things were when working with children."

Sarah felt a surge of excitement as she recognized the problem-solving mode that Dr. Hendricks was entering, the same mental state that had helped the administrator navigate countless hospital crises over the years. "We could start with a very limited pilot program," she suggested. "Maybe just one or two sessions, heavily supervised, with older children who are dealing with longer-term stays. If Lyn could help even a few kids process their medical experiences through art, it would be worth exploring further."

Officer Martinez cleared his throat, clearly uncomfortable with the direction this conversation was taking. "Dr. Hendricks, I have to express some concerns about the security implications of having someone of this size moving freely through the hospital. Our current protocols and physical infrastructure weren't designed to accommodate individuals with these kinds of unusual characteristics."

Before Hendricks could respond, one of the painted nurses stepped forward. It was Jennifer Walsh, a veteran pediatric nurse whose face still bore traces of the blue and gold design that Lyn had applied earlier. Sarah knew Jennifer by reputation as someone who had worked with sick children for over twenty years, developing an almost intuitive understanding of what helped young patients cope with medical trauma.

"Excuse me, Dr. Hendricks," Jennifer said, her voice carrying the authority that came from decades of patient care experience. "I know this morning was frightening and completely inappropriate in terms of how it happened, but I have to say something about Lyn's artistic abilities." She gestured toward her painted face, which even in its partially cleaned state showed evidence of remarkable skill and sensitivity. "This isn't just random decoration. The color choices she made for each of us were somehow perfectly suited to our individual personalities and energy. She managed to see something essential about each person and translate it into visual form. That kind of intuitive artistic response could be incredibly valuable when working with children who are struggling to express their fears and hopes about their medical situations."

Sarah felt a wave of gratitude toward Jennifer for this unexpected support. Having a respected pediatric nurse advocate for Lyn's potential contributions carried far more weight than Sarah's own arguments, especially since Jennifer had direct experience with both Lyn's artistic methods and the needs of young patients.

Dr. Hendricks nodded thoughtfully, her expression suggesting that Jennifer's perspective had added an important dimension to her decision-making process. "Jennifer, you've worked with our child life specialists on art therapy initiatives before. Do you think there's a realistic possibility that Lyn's skills could be adapted to therapeutic purposes?"

Jennifer looked up at Lyn's enormous, tear-streaked face, then back at Dr. Hendricks. "I think it's worth finding out," she said firmly. "Some of our long-term pediatric patients have been in the hospital for months. They've exhausted the usual recreational activities, they're dealing with complex emotions about their treatments, and they need new ways to express what they're going through. If Lyn could work with our child life team to create safe, structured artistic experiences, it might open up entirely new possibilities for helping these kids process their medical journeys."

Lyn wiped her eyes again, leaving more streaks of transferred paint across her cheeks. "I would be so careful with the children," she said, her voice filled with earnest intensity. "Emma always told me about how brave her young patients were, how they faced things that would terrify most adults. I would never want to add to their fear or confusion. But maybe... maybe I could help them feel less alone with their big emotions the way I feel less alone with mine when I'm creating something beautiful."

The security officers exchanged glances, clearly uncertain about how to process a situation where a potential security threat was evolving into a possible therapeutic resource. Officer Cooper, who had earlier shared her own experience with grief, seemed particularly thoughtful as she observed the conversation unfolding around her.

"Dr. Hendricks," Cooper said hesitantly, "my brother's daughter spent two months in the children's ward at Walter Reed after he was injured overseas. The art therapy programs they had there made a huge difference in helping her process her dad's situation. If there's a chance that Ms. Patterson could provide something similar for the kids here, maybe it's worth considering the security challenges as problems to be solved rather than reasons to dismiss the opportunity entirely."

Sarah could see that the momentum was shifting toward possibility rather than prohibition, though she knew that Dr. Hendricks was still weighing significant practical and legal considerations. The administrator was known for her willingness to take calculated risks when the potential benefits justified the complications, but she was also responsible for the safety and well-being of everyone in the hospital.

"Ms. Patterson," Dr. Hendricks said, addressing Lyn directly, "if we were to explore some kind of structured pilot program, would you be willing to work within very specific parameters? Scheduled sessions in designated spaces, with multiple staff members present at all times, following protocols designed to ensure everyone's safety and comfort?"

Lyn nodded eagerly, her massive frame somehow managing to convey both enthusiasm and respect for the seriousness of what was being discussed. "I would follow any rules you needed me to follow," she said. "I understand that trust has to be earned, especially after what I did this morning. I just want to find a way to honor Emma's memory by helping people instead of frightening them."

Dr. Hendricks was quiet for a long moment, her sharp eyes moving between Lyn's hopeful expression, the painted nurses who were listening intently to the conversation, and the security officers who were clearly struggling to adapt their standard procedures to this unprecedented situation. Sarah could almost see the administrator's mind working through contingency plans, risk assessments, and the kind of creative problem-solving that had made her legendary within the hospital system.

"Here's what we're going to do," Hendricks said finally, her voice carrying the decisive tone that indicated a major decision had been reached. "Ms. Patterson, you're going to spend the rest of today in the hospital chapel with Dr. Levinson and our chief child life specialist, discussing the theoretical framework for therapeutic art programming. If that conversation goes well, we'll schedule a single trial session next week with two of our older pediatric patients who have been dealing with extended stays. The session will be held in the large conference room on the third floor, with multiple staff members present and strict protocols in place for everyone's safety."

Sarah felt her heart racing with excitement and anxiety as she realized that Dr. Hendricks was actually moving forward with this improbable idea. The risks were significant, but the potential benefits for the hospital's young patients could be transformative if Lyn's artistic abilities could be successfully channeled toward therapeutic purposes.

Lyn's face lit up with the first genuine smile Sarah had seen from her, an expression so radiantly hopeful that it transformed her entire presence despite her impossible size. "Thank you," she whispered, her voice thick with emotion. "Thank you for giving me a chance to try to help instead of just taking people away from their work. Emma would be so proud to know that her hospital family was willing to find creative ways to care for children."

Officer Martinez still looked uncertain about the whole arrangement, but he nodded respectfully toward Dr. Hendricks' decision. "We'll need to work out some logistical details about movement through the hospital and emergency procedures," he said. "But if you think this is worth trying, we'll find ways to make it work safely."**Chapter 3**

The hospital chapel had been designed as a sanctuary of peace, with soaring ceilings that rose nearly twenty feet and tall windows that filled the space with gentle afternoon light. For the first time since her transformation, Lyn found herself in a room where she could stand fully upright without hunching her shoulders or worrying about hitting her head on fixtures meant for people of normal stature. She moved carefully through the space, her enormous hands clasped respectfully in front of her as she took in the simple beauty of the interfaith sanctuary that served patients and families from all religious backgrounds.

Dr. Sarah Levinson sat in one of the wooden pews, watching as Lyn explored the chapel with the reverent curiosity of someone discovering a space where they truly belonged. The giant woman paused before the large stained glass window that dominated the eastern wall, her head tilted as she studied the way colored light played across the floor in shifting patterns that changed with the movement of clouds outside. There was something almost childlike in Lyn's wonder at this simple architectural beauty, a quality that made Sarah think about the children they hoped she might soon be working with.

"Emma loved stained glass windows," Lyn said softly, her voice carrying easily through the acoustically designed space without echoing harshly the way it did in the hospital corridors. "She used to say that they were like hope made visible, taking ordinary light and transforming it into something that could lift people's spirits even on difficult days. She had a collection of photographs she'd taken of church windows from all over the city, and she would show them to her young patients when they needed something beautiful to focus on during uncomfortable procedures."

Sarah felt a pang of recognition at this detail, remembering her own tendency to collect small beautiful things during her years of working in the restaurant industry. She had kept a folder of photographs on her phone—interesting architectural details, unexpected moments of natural beauty, amusing customer interactions—that she would review during particularly stressful shifts to remind herself that the world contained more than just the immediate pressures of taking orders and delivering food. The impulse to gather beauty as a form of emotional survival seemed to be something that people in caregiving professions developed instinctively.

The hospital corridors echoed with an unusual tension that Thursday morning, though Dr. Sarah Levinson couldn't quite put her finger on what felt different. She'd traded her waiter's apron for scrubs only six months ago, having finally completed her medical degree after years of night shifts at Romano's Diner in downtown Dallas. The transition from taking orders for chicken fried steak to taking vital signs had been jarring, but nothing could have prepared her for what she was about to encounter.

The first sign something was amiss came when Nurse Patricia Williams didn't show up for her shift. Patricia was notorious for her punctuality—she'd arrive exactly seventeen minutes early every day, coffee in hand, already reviewing patient charts. When her replacement mentioned that Patricia had called in with a peculiar story about being "wrapped up" in some kind of art project, Sarah felt the first flutter of unease in her chest.

"Wrapped up how?" Sarah asked, adjusting her stethoscope as they walked past the pediatric wing.

"That's the thing," replied Nurse Jenkins, a heavyset woman whose shoes squeaked against the linoleum with every step. "She said she couldn't move her arms properly, something about toilet paper and paint. Made no sense whatsoever. Administration thinks she might be having some kind of breakdown."

Sarah nodded absently, but her mind was already racing. She'd heard whispers over the past week about strange disappearances, about nurses who would simply vanish for hours at a time before reappearing with confused expressions and mysterious white residue on their uniforms. The other doctors dismissed it as gossip, the kind of idle chatter that flourished in any workplace where people worked long hours under stress.

But Sarah remembered something from her waitressing days that made her take these stories more seriously. She'd learned to pay attention to patterns, to the subtle signs that something was building toward a crisis. In the restaurant business, you learned to spot trouble before it erupted—the customer who'd had one drink too many, the kitchen staff member who was about to snap under pressure, the small incidents that preceded the big disasters.

The morning rounds proceeded normally until they reached the seventh floor, where the geriatric ward housed some of their most vulnerable patients. Sarah was checking on Mrs. Henderson, an eighty-three-year-old woman recovering from hip surgery, when she heard the screaming.

It wasn't the typical hospital screaming—not pain or fear or medical emergency—but something else entirely. A sound of pure bewilderment mixed with what could only be described as artistic frustration. Sarah dropped Mrs. Henderson's chart and rushed toward the sound, her heart pounding as she rounded the corner into the main hallway.

What she saw defied immediate comprehension. A figure that had to be at least nine feet tall was carefully, almost tenderly, wrapping Nurse Rodriguez in what appeared to be several layers of toilet paper. The giant moved with surprising delicacy, rotating the terrified nurse like a mannequin while applying the paper in precise, overlapping spirals. But what made the scene even more surreal was that Rodriguez's face and hands had been painted in brilliant shades of blue and gold, creating an effect that was simultaneously beautiful and deeply unsettling.

"Stop!" Sarah shouted, though her voice came out as more of a croak than a command.

The giant paused and turned toward her, and Sarah found herself looking into the most profoundly sad eyes she'd ever encountered. The face was feminine, with features that might have been considered beautiful if not for their impossible scale and the expression of grief so deep it seemed to emanate from every pore. Tears the size of raindrops fell steadily from those enormous eyes, creating small puddles on the hospital floor.

"I'm making them beautiful," the giant said, her voice a low rumble that seemed to vibrate through Sarah's bones. "They work so hard, they deserve to be beautiful."

Sarah forced herself to take a step closer, fighting every instinct that screamed at her to run. "What's your name?"

"Lyn," the giant replied, never stopping her careful wrapping motions. "I used to be smaller. I used to be different. But the sadness made me grow."

"The sadness?"

Lyn's massive hands paused in their work, and for a moment the only sound was Nurse Rodriguez's muffled whimpering from beneath her toilet paper cocoon. "My daughter worked in a hospital. She took care of people, just like these beautiful nurses. But nobody took care of her when she needed it most."

Sarah felt her training kick in, the same calm professionalism that had helped her handle difficult customers during her waitressing years. "I'm sorry about your daughter, Lyn. But these nurses—they're scared. They have families who need them to come home."

"They will go home," Lyn said, carefully tucking the end of the toilet paper into Rodriguez's wrapping. "They'll go home more beautiful than when they left. Art makes everything better. Art makes pain into something people can look at."

Before Sarah could respond, Lyn lifted the wrapped nurse with impossible gentleness and placed her in a wheelchair that she'd apparently commandeered from somewhere else in the hospital. Rodriguez sat there like an enormous toilet paper sculpture, only her painted face visible, eyes wide with shock but otherwise unharmed.

"You see?" Lyn said, stepping back to admire her work. "Beautiful. Peaceful. Safe."

Sarah realized with growing horror that this wasn't random violence or even mental illness in any conventional sense. This was grief transformed into something else entirely, grief that had somehow taken physical form and grown beyond all normal boundaries. The giant's movements were too purposeful, too artistic, too filled with genuine care to be the product of simple madness.

"How many nurses have you... decorated?" Sarah asked, trying to keep her voice steady.

Lyn's expression brightened slightly, the way a child's face might light up when asked about a favorite hobby. "Seven so far today. Each one different colors, different patterns. The morning shift nurses are blues and greens—cool colors for cool morning light. The afternoon shift will be warmer. Oranges and reds and yellows."

Sarah's mind raced as she tried to process this information. Seven nurses. That explained the staffing shortages, the confused phone calls, the growing sense of chaos that had been building throughout the morning. But where were the others? And more importantly, how had a nine-foot-tall giant managed to move through the hospital without setting off every alarm and security protocol they had?

As if reading her thoughts, Lyn gestured toward a supply closet whose door stood slightly ajar. "They're resting in there. Waiting for the unveiling."

Sarah edged toward the closet, her hands shaking as she reached for the handle. Inside, arranged like an art installation, sat six more toilet paper wrapped figures. Each one had been painted in different color schemes, and each sat perfectly still in what appeared to be states of resigned bewilderment. They were breathing, they were unharmed, but they were essentially immobilized by their elaborate wrappings.

"This has to stop, Lyn," Sarah said, turning back to face the giant. "These people aren't art supplies. They're human beings with lives and responsibilities."

Lyn's face crumpled, and a fresh wave of tears began flowing down her cheeks. "But they're so tired. They work so hard. When I wrap them up, they can rest. When I paint them, they become something more than just tired nurses in a difficult world."

Sarah found herself in the strangest position of her life—trying to provide therapy to a grief-stricken giant who was systematically gift-wrapping the hospital staff. Her medical training hadn't covered this scenario, but her years of dealing with difficult customers had taught her something about de-escalation and finding common ground with people who were acting irrationally.

"Tell me about your daughter," she said, settling into a chair that put her roughly at eye level with Lyn's kneecaps. "What was her name?"

The giant's expression softened immediately. "Emma. Emma Louise Patterson. She was a pediatric nurse at Children's Memorial. Twenty-six years old, the most beautiful heart you ever saw." Lyn's voice grew quieter, more distant. "She worked double shifts because they were short-staffed. She slept four hours a night because there was always another child who needed care. She gave everything she had to that job."

"What happened to her?"

Lyn's massive form seemed to shrink slightly, her shoulders sagging under the weight of memory. "Car accident on her way home from a thirty-six hour shift. She fell asleep at the wheel. The grief... it changed me. Made me bigger. Made me want to protect all the other nurses, all the other daughters who give too much of themselves away."

Sarah felt her heart breaking for this strange, impossible woman. The logic was twisted, but the love behind it was genuine. Lyn wasn't trying to hurt anyone—she was trying to protect them in the only way her grief-transformed mind could conceive.

"Emma sounds like she was an amazing person," Sarah said carefully. "But do you think she would want you to frighten her colleagues? To wrap them up so they can't do their jobs?"

Lyn considered this question with obvious difficulty, her enormous brow furrowed in concentration. Around them, the hospital continued to function, though Sarah could hear the growing commotion as more staff discovered the situation. Soon, security would arrive, probably followed by police, and this delicate moment of communication would be lost in chaos and conflict.

"I don't know," Lyn admitted finally. "I just know that the sadness gets so big sometimes that I have to do something with it. And when I'm painting, when I'm wrapping, it feels like I'm taking care of people the way Emma used to take care of people."

Sarah felt a sudden clarity wash over her, the same intuitive understanding that had helped her navigate countless difficult situations during her years in the service industry. She stood up slowly, making sure her movements were calm and non-threatening, and walked over to where Nurse Rodriguez sat in her toilet paper cocoon. With gentle fingers, she began to unwrap the frightened woman, peeling away layer after layer of the elaborate binding.

"What are you doing?" Lyn asked, her voice rising in alarm. "She's not finished yet. The paint needs more time to set, and the wrapping provides the structural integrity for the piece."

"I'm helping her breathe better," Sarah explained, continuing her careful work. "You know, Lyn, there might be a different way to honor Emma's memory. A way that helps people instead of frightening them." As she worked, Sarah's mind was racing through possibilities, drawing on every ounce of creativity and problem-solving ability she'd developed over her unconventional path to medicine.

Rodriguez emerged from her wrappings like a colorful butterfly, gasping with relief but still decorated in the elaborate face paint that Lyn had applied. The blue and gold design was actually quite striking, Sarah had to admit, though the terror in the nurse's eyes somewhat diminished the artistic effect. Rodriguez stumbled away toward the elevator, probably to report the situation to security, but Sarah barely noticed. Her attention was focused entirely on the giant woman whose grief had taken such an extraordinary physical form.

"Tell me more about Emma's work," Sarah said, settling back into her chair. "What kind of art did she like? Did you two ever do creative projects together?"

Lyn's expression grew wistful, and she lowered herself carefully to sit cross-legged on the hospital floor, her massive frame still towering over Sarah even in this position. "Emma loved children's book illustrations. She used to say that a good picture could make a sick child forget their pain for a few minutes. She kept art supplies in her locker at work, would draw little pictures for her patients when she had time between rounds."

Sarah felt pieces of a plan beginning to form in her mind. "What if we could find a way to continue Emma's work? What if instead of wrapping up the nurses, you could help them create something beautiful for the children in the pediatric ward?"

The giant's tears slowed slightly, and Sarah could see genuine interest flickering in those enormous, sad eyes. "You mean... make art that helps people feel better instead of just making them look beautiful?"

"Exactly," Sarah said, her confidence growing as the idea took shape. "Emma knew that art could be healing. She used it to help children cope with difficult medical procedures. Maybe that's the real way to honor her memory—not by protecting nurses from their work, but by helping them do their work more effectively."
